Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 5bc265338cfeb7def47f45b4eef0efdc1cf1e751
lg2 can handle strings, so you don't need the c_str()

lg2 can also handle exceptions, so you can just pass in 'ex'

https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-logging/blob/master/lib/include/phosphor-logging/lg2/conversion.hpp#L265

Suggestion: "EXCEPTION" is more readable than "EXC".

The same comment is applicable everywhere.
I think, it is pdbg target path, not location code so we should define like below `TARGET_PATH`
We could use attribute name itself. `ATTR_PHYS_BIN_PATH`

I don't think a break this way would print right, but clang-format should be smart enough to allow unbroken strings go over 80 characters - https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-logging/blob/master/.clang-format#L51

if it's too long, you can also break it like how it previously was.  here is the same using lg2 already https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-logging/blob/master/extensions/openpower-pels/pel.cpp#L910
ok got it. Removed line breaks.

I feel it is duplicate data since lg2 supports to print function name natively.

Could please check this?

FYR: https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-logging/blob/master/lib/lg2_logger.cpp#L231
On my analysis it is observed that the binary/daemon name along with PID is getting printed natively. Function name is not getting printed.

We cannot see it in the pretty format, we need to see in the verbose mode

For example
```
journalctl -u <service_name> -o verbose

CODE_FILE=..
CODE_FUNC=..
CODE_LINE=..
```

Anyway, its pain to see from the verbose mode so we need to include in the MESSAGE itself but, thats out of the scope.

and we will get verbose traces from the BMC dump so, I am good if need to find out the location of the traces. https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-debug-collector/blob/master/tools/dreport.d/plugins.d/journalpid
Same as mentioned in other place. lg2 print function name natively.
it does but you have to look at the verbose journal to see it which is painful.
On my analysis it is observed that the binary/daemon name along with PID is getting printed natively. Function name is not getting printed.
Replied in the another similar comment.As Matt pointed out, its pain to see in verbose mode.
same comment about the line breaks as before
line break in trace is not required as mentioned in other place.
FFDC_FD? The same comment is applicable in all places.
Used FD because in old trace also variable name was 'fd'
this would be a good opportunity to combine this line with the line above it and just do it all with lg2
+1 and we could avoid `c_str()` as well.
same comment as above, can combine.
yea, here's another example that shows a good way to line break
You can leave out the 'CALLOUT_TYPE=' since you already have that in the text before it.
you can just do:  invalid symbolic FRU {FRU}

nit: this would flow a bit better like:

MRU callout section in PEL with <num> MRUs has listed size <size> that doesn't match actual size <actual size>
you'll want trailing spaces on the end of these so when they're concatentated it'll look right.
+1, I will also prefer to form a message with value instead of adding message and separately.
same comment about trailing spaces needed when you break strings like this

nit:  looks like a typo in the original trace, would look better as
"GUARD: " instead of "GUARD :"
